awd_titl_txt: PFI-RP: Scalable Fabrication of Flexible Electronics and Solar Cells with Improved Environmental Stability
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercialization potential of this Partnerships for Innovation-Research Partnerships (PFI-RP) project is to enable commercialization of inexpensive, lightweight, and flexible electronic devices with high performance and a long lifetime. The materials developed here will improve the performance of devices across several markets and the process will be compatible with high-throughput manufacturing.  This will impact several types of devices with high market potential, enabling displays with lower power consumption and higher brightness, as well as solar cells with extended useful lifetimes.  The devices can be thin and semi-transparent for solar windows or for see-through displays, and they can be encapsulated in glass to provide an impermeable hermetic barrier. This PFI will enable the founding of one or more startups in these market spaces, which will in turn lead to employment opportunities and economic development. Moreover, this project will train one postdoctoral researcher and 9 undergraduates with skills in instrumentation development, material deposition, and characterization methods. Students will also receive valuable skills in innovation, entrepreneurship and commercialization through participation in an innovative team-based course. Students from groups that are underrepresented in STEM fields will be particularly recruited to participate in the project.

The proposed project addresses the need for large grain-size crystalline semiconductor thin films with greatly improved properties for a wide range of devices.  For field-effect transistors, grain size larger than the transistor channel length leads to improved charge carrier mobility, which enables brighter displays.  In photovoltaic cells based on hybrid organic-inorganic perovskite materials, large grain size suppresses degradation mechanisms occurring at grain boundaries.  Solution-based thin films deposition can deliver these advantages, while also being readily compatible with high-throughput roll-to-roll manufacturing processes.  This project takes recent advances in research on deposition from liquid solutions to the next level by scaling up the writing heads and adopting roll-to-roll methods. The anticipated technical results include the construction of a deposition unit that will be used to demonstrate an array of Organic Field Effect Transistors, which will be integrated with Organic Light Emitting Diode pixels to form a simple display.  A second unit will be used to demonstrate perovskite photovoltaic cells with improved properties.  Long lifetime and improved environmental stability will be achieved through control of thin film properties such as grain size, through the use of thin flexible glass substrates with high hermeticity, and through glass-to-glass bonding by a laser sealing method.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The broader impact of this project stems from equipment and techniques to enable rapid development of inexpensive, lightweight, and flexible electronic devices with high performance and long lifetime.  Multiple thin film coating devices were developed with a goal of achieving simple yet functional designs to enable rapid iteration of coating parameters, while also maintaining translatability to manufacturing-scale roll-to-roll printing.  The final coating design that was adopted was named the Microslot Writer due to its similarity to conventional slot die coating equipment.  A key difference of the Microslot Writer is that it is gravity fed, making it useful for fast iteration, while slot die coaters have proven to be cumbersome due to their complex pumping systems and relatively large dead volumes that require purging, disassembly, and cleaning after each trial. Through testing with several new and established materials systems and device types, it was established that the Microslot Writer can produce excellent uniformity in laboratory-scale thin films, with thicknesses down to a few nanometers and up to more than one micron for typical crystalline semiconductor layers.

 The project team participated in NSF I-Corps, which included meeting with over 100 potential customers.   Multiple commercial markets were considered, such (i) as thin film coating equipment manufacturing, and (i) thin film device manufacturing for markets such as transistor arrays for active-matrix flat panel displays, and thin film photovoltaic cells. It was determined that there is an outstanding commercial opportunity in thin film solar modules.  Lightweight modules have the potential to greatly reduce installation costs and they can be installed on low-load rooftops and other situations where conventional solar panels are not practical.   Thin film solar based on metal halide perovskite have a particularly strong motivation because perovskites materials have the right properties to make highly efficient solar cells from inexpensive materials.  Metal halide perovskite solar cells can also be manufactured by less energy intensive processes compared to silicon, reducing the carbon emissions from their manufacturing.

 This project resulted in the founding of a startup company, Verde Technologies, to manufacture lightweight, flexible perovskite solar modules.  The outcomes described above will likely have an impact on production of clean energy, reducing carbon emissions, sustainable manufacturing, and employment opportunities in the clean energy sector.

 This project included training of one postdoctoral researcher, two graduate students and 11 undergraduate students (including 5 from underrepresented groups) with skills in instrumentation development, thin film deposition, and characterization methods. Students also acquired skills in entrepreneurship, and commercialization through participation in team-based programs. An outcome of the entrepreneurial training is that the postdoctoral researcher involved in this project founded the startup company and two of the undergraduate students also joined the company.  They have raised $1.5M in grants, awards, and investments. Recently the company has re-incorporated as a Public Benefit Corporation. Other notable successes include winning the Countdown phase of the Perovskite Startup Prize competition and being the U.S. National Runner up in the CleanTech Open accelerator.

 The intellectual merit of this project is derived from rapid optimization of solution coating methods for several applications.  Initial work centered on the hypothesis that large crystalline semiconductor grains are beneficial for both transistors and photovoltaic cells. Arrays of organic field effect transistors (OFETs) were fabricated using a high carrier mobility semiconductor material (C8-BTBT) on top of SiO2 to form the transistor channel.   This work was de-prioritized after year 1, partly due to a large 40% transistor-to-transistor variation in OFET carrier mobility due to nonuniformities in the crystallization during solution coating, and because display manufacturers were focused on other backplane transistor technologies such as laser recrystallized silicon or oxide semiconductors.  These competing technologies limit commercialization potential of OFETs transistors arrays at the present time.  Instead, the project was pivoted to photovoltaic cells due to the emergence of lead halide perovskites as a promising thin film material for photovoltaics.

 Unlike organic semiconductors where large crystalline grain size is beneficial if the grain size can be made larger than the transistor channel length, the dominant focus in perovskite photovoltaics is on the deposition of dense, pinhole-free films with highly uniform thickness.  Achieving high performing devices at large area depends on control of the crystallization process by tuning solvent systems, passivation layers, and drying methods, as well as attention to how well chemistries transfer and scale up.  The deposition equipment developed for this project enabled rapid iteration, which led to steady improvement in key parameters such as efficiency and fill factor. Significant effort was put into developing and scaling inverted devices based on formamidinium lead iodide (FAPI).  Efficiencies >18% and fill factors >80% were achieved for small cells (0.15 cm2 area) with some drop off in performance for larger areas.  These results are competitive among perovskite startups, and are approaching the best research results, which typically employ solution coating methods such as spin coating that are not scalable.

 


Last Modified: 07/25/2023
Modified by: Randall L Headrick
